The forest gives way to rocks and green hills, but among the tall trees are numerous monkeys, sitting in small groups, loud, yet shorter than half your size. They distort the green leaves with red, brown, white, and blue fur.

As you approach their territory, their excitement grows. They climb up and down the trunks, sway on vines, jump between branches, or hang down, putting to use their long tails. They throw at you countless angry glances and grunts, but also cones, branches, and chestnuts.

A piece of their fresh feces lands close to {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}, but the pack’s aim is rather miserable.
I’ll scatter them with the use of my wand. [[Cost: {color=#f6d6bd}[manacost]{/color}]

You unwrap the linen sheet and grab the willow wand, still as smooth as on the day you bought it. The pointy, carved branch is thin, but heavy from the injected quicksilver. You raise it as if you are about to stab the air with a dagger, then take a swing.

The invisible wave hits the leaves and its little dwellers, sending a few of them into the air, while others are hugging the branches desperately. The rustling mixes with furious screams. They monkeys move away, and give you worried, respectful glances.
I ride forward, holding the wand in the air.
- I ride forward, holding the wand in the air.

You approach one of the crowded trees, holding your trusted axe. The creatures spread at first, but then surround you and your palfrey, throwing at you anything they can grab while staying among the branches. You cover your face, but to no avail.

Two animals move to the lower branches, and cackle as they effortlessly dodge your swipes. Your angry shout is met with mocking howls.

A few more creatures get on the ground. A lucky rock reaches your forehead, making you retreat.
I climb into the saddle and rush {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}.
- I climb into the saddle and rush {color=#f6d6bd}%s{/color}.
You’ve got %s quarrels left.
{i}You lost two quarrels. You’ve got %s quarrels left.{/i}

Loading a crossbow from the saddle isn’t easy, but you’ve got time. You catch the second quarrel with your teeth, aim carefully, and pull the trigger.

The colorful beast falls down in silence. Its companions point at the fallen shell, shouting as it doesn’t move. The panic spreads through the troop, giving you time to reload. Soon, another creature hits the ground, this time screaming in pain.

The monkeys flee through the trees and either hide behind the trunks, or observe you from denser leaves.
I ride forward, shaking my weapon in the air.
- I ride forward, shaking my weapon in the air.

You press the horn to your lips and after the first, failed attempt, you fill the woods with a terrifying shout of a monster. The screams of the troop gets higher and whinier, and the creatures flee through the trees and either hide behind the trunks, or observe the woods from denser leaves.

When some of monkeys turn toward you again, you’re already crossing the path. They give you worried, respectful glances.
I ride forward, holding the horn in the air.
- I ride forward, holding the horn in the air.
{i}-1 appearance point.{/i}

You ride through the avalanche of missiles, and while the eyes and foreheads of both you and your palfrey are covered, you both experience some painful hits as you move forward. Thankfully, the monkeys don’t chase you for long, and after maybe a minute, they stay at the edge of their home, only yelling at you.
I take a deep breath, noting to myself that I should clean my shield if I pass any streams.
- I take a deep breath, noting to myself that I should clean my shield if I pass any streams.

Surprisingly, there’s not that many missiles around, as if the creatures’ zeal has been subdued by the previous ineffectiveness of their attacks. The few items that fall on you are bothersome, but nothing you can’t handle. Thankfully, the monkeys don’t chase you for long, and after maybe a minute, they stay at the edge of their home, only yelling at you.
I ride forward, noting to myself that I should clean my shield if I pass any streams.

A couple of missiles fall on your cover or hit {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}, who snorts with frustration, but other than that, you’re safe. You get to the other side of the troop’s home in no time, and while the monkeys stay loud, they don’t pursue you anymore.

A few beasts get in front of you, slowing you down and mocking you with their screams, but they aren’t goblins - they keep running back, limiting themselves to threats.

You rush {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}, which is more than happy to follow your command. The monkeys follow you, swinging between the trees, until they reach the edge of their territory, letting out triumphant shouts.

Your ride goes mostly undisturbed. A couple of missiles fall on your bags, or hit {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]’s{/color} side, but that’s about it. You reach the edge of the troop’s territory in no time, and while the monkeys stay loud, they don’t pursue you anymore.

The air in these bright, arid hills is much drier than in the woods. Down below, among the humble meadows, you spot a stone plateau, on top of which a group of bipedal creatures is feasting on a large carcass. From what you can see, only a few of them would reach your knees, but as the pack notices your gaze, it starts to regroup.
For now, I just observe them.
- For now, I just observe them.

Kobolds, known for their long tails and colorful scales, rarely bother humans. Their small saurian paws are dabbling in the puddle of blood left by their meal, ribs of which are sticking out of the lacerated stomach.

While they make a lot of noise and keep running all over the place, they are far from presenting the threat of the dragonlings. There’s about eight of them, and no reinforcements among the rock faces.

The dead animal resembles a mouflon, or an ibex.
{image=d6} I tether {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color} to a tree. I can handle a few bites from their tiny jaws.

You grab your [custom1] head toward the crag slowly. Climbing to the top is simple enough. You step forward and take a few swings, raising your voice in your taunts.

The beasts keep running left and right, stretching out their shells, jumping up, and warning you with their shrieks. They are quick, nimble, and as loud as a bird.

Finally, the largest kobold, whose head is covered with red scales, runs to the rock face, and makes an impressive jump onto the higher ledge. The others follow it, leaving you with a few more discontent screeches.

You doubt it’s the first time their prey gets stolen.
I examine the carcass.
- I examine the carcass.
It’s an ibex, with brown, elegant fur. Its black horns were broken in half. There’s a red knot attached to one of its front ankles. A sign of ownership.
I leave it to the scavengers.
- I leave it to the scavengers.
{i}-1 armor point.{/i}

You grab your [custom1] head toward the crag slowly. Climbing to the top is simple enough. You step forward and take a few swings, raising your voice in your taunts.

The beasts keep running left and right, stretching out their shells, jumping up, and warning you with their shrieks. They are quick, nimble, and as loud as a bird.

Finally, the largest kobold, whose head is covered with red scales, risks an attack. It gets close enough to take a hit in the maw, and while its nearest companions follow its lead, the others hesitate. One of them manages to reach your sleeve, tearing it as you lift it up, but you then grab it and throw it away, right into another member of its pack.

After that, the entire group runs to the rock face, and makes impressive jumps onto the higher ledges, leaving you with a few more discontent screeches. You doubt it’s the first time their prey gets stolen.

Every minute or so, you get lost in the dense woods. When possible, you stick to the remains of the beaten path, clearing the overgrown thicket that blocks your way, but it would take many more travelers to sustain such a trail.

The land around you may lack greens, but is far from being empty. The fallen boughs and dead stumps are slowly devoured by ants and mushrooms, a web-like labyrinth of wooden walls, while the white termites, larger than your hands, continue their never-ending march. Their “guards” notice your presence, but simply form a warning line in front of their workers.

The trees are taller than the temple in the city, with trunks resembling the legs of giants. The shadows they cast are like a carpet, and the few beams of light nourish the sparse bushes and ferns, the only plants that aren’t choked by the rotting, late-summer leaves, shaped like toothed squares, as large as your face.
Now that I’m more familiar with this part of the forest, I may be able to find a smoother path.
- Now that I’m more familiar with this part of the forest, I may be able to find a smoother path.

The distant roar gets louder as you ride forward, and is quickly followed by the obnoxious screeching of runners. You notice the sounds of breaking branches, and of powerful paws trampling the soil. The shouts of anger and fear.
I follow the sounds.
- I follow the sounds.

The tall trees cover you with the shadows. You’re forced to get on your boots to move beneath a few of the fallen boughs. Soon, you reach a few shrubs at the edge of the fighting ground, and tether your mount nearby.

You count six birds spread around the dry glade. They’re as tall as your palfrey, with pointy, curved beaks and tiny wings. Their feathers are green, blue, and white.

The saurian, surrounded by the predators, looks like it could break their necks with just a breath. It matches your height, but it’s as wide as it is tall, and as long as a house, even without its long tail. It’s covered with firm plates, aligned in horizontal rows down the entire shell, and its head resembles a horned helmet. On its sides are two rows of irregular spikes, each of them longer than your forearm. The creature swings its tail left and right, scaring off the runners with the massive “club” at its end.
Surely some bird beaks won’t get through the dragon’s scutes?
- Surely some bird beaks won’t get through the dragon’s scutes?

pagan

By the monster’s side you notice its descendant, gurgling in fear, too small and weak to protect itself. The runners don’t have to rely on their muscles - they’re fast, nimble, and keep their distance easily. Their constant shouts and disorienting movements force their victims to walk in place, swinging the tree-breaking weapon to no avail.

If the predators make a mistake, the dragon will crush one of them, scaring the flock away. Otherwise, the saurian will break the neck of its child with a single wrong step.

One of the birds spots you and, shocked, starts to flap its wings and squawk.
The United Church would rejoice at the sight of a dead dragon. I don’t intervene.
- The United Church would rejoice at the sight of a dead dragon. I don’t intervene.

You ride away. After a minute. you hear a painful roar. You look back, only to notice that one of the trees starts to crack, falling down like a tower hit by lightning. The earth shakes, causing {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]’s{/color} snort. The centuries-old juices of the plant are now nothing more than a meal - just like the dragon’s scion.
Every dead dragon secures the fate of humankind.
- Every dead dragon secures the fate of humankind.
My ancestors would not intervene. The forest needs to be its own master.
- My ancestors would not intervene. The forest needs to be its own master.
The spirits know which animal ought to survive.
- The spirits know which animal ought to survive.
I try to scare away the birds.
- I try to scare away the birds.

With the axe in your hand, you jump out of the shrubs, shouting at the nearest two runners. In return, they “bow” to you, raising their voices, then straighten up, shaking their colorful heads. Despite this display, they step back, not sure what’s happening.

You swing your weapon, making yourself look as wide as you can. The birds start to regroup, allowing the roaring giant to get closer to them. After the first bird flees into the trees, the others follow.

The winner is still swinging its tail, observing you, but sparing you the further noise. The little dragon steps away and imitates the movements of its parent, though if anything, it looks more like a play.
Time to get out of here.
- I move away before the dragon turns me into a sheet of parchment.
You lead {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color} away, step on a stump, and climb into the saddle. From behind you comes a triumphant roar.
I’m just glad I saved the dragonling.
- I’m just glad I saved the dragonling.
Just doing my work. Runners are a bigger threat to travelers.
- Just doing my work. Runners are a bigger threat to travelers.
Too bad I couldn’t steal that creature.
- Too bad I couldn’t steal that creature.
Once the dragonling gets older, it may be turned into a nice few piles of coins.
- Once the dragonling gets older, it may be turned into a nice few piles of coins.
I help the birds.
- I help the birds.

With the axe in your hand, you jump out of the shrubs and stride toward the dragon. The surprised runner “bows” to you, raising its voice, but seeing how you keep your distances, it just shakes its colorful head and moves away.

The saurian pays close attention to your approach, not sure what’s going on. During this moment of hesitation, a member of the flock gets close enough to peck the monster’s head. The terrified creature starts turning around.

The loud steps cover up the shout of the trampled dragonling, to the birds’ joyful screech. The dragon tries one last attack, furiously moving backwards after one of the runners. It takes a wide swing with its tail, but the club hits only the trunk of the nearest tree.

The plant starts to crack, like a tower hit by lightning. The earth trembles, and as you look at {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}, it panically pulls the rope, trying to set itself free.

You’re not quick enough to escape the powerful landing of the tree. The ground shakes, the deafening thud pushes you into the ground. The centuries-old juices of the plant are now nothing more than a meal - just like the dragon’s scion.

You get up, cut the rope, and lead your palfrey away, barely stopping it from leaving you behind. With a grunt, you climb into the saddle.
One less dragon to worry about.
- One less dragon to worry about.
No wall would stop such a monster. I need to mention it once I reach the city.
- No wall would stop such a monster. I need to mention it once I reach the city.
Too bad I couldn’t hurt any of the runners as well.
- Too bad I couldn’t hurt any of the runners as well.
I stay out of this.
- I stay out of this.
That’s just how it is.
- That’s just how it is.
Not my problem. I head forward.
- Not my problem. I head forward.

You spot a ten-year-old, dark tree that’s about twice your height, yet looks like a sapling when compared to the giants around it. Its thin branches are leafless, hanging like the limbs of an exhausted worker.

Right under the tree there’s a dead, red boar, too large for you to lift it. Its tusk could be worth a few coins, but the scavengers may show up any moment now.

The colors of leaves range from greens to purples, and overwhelm you with shadows. The stems of the shrubs twisted in all directions, seeking the slightest scraps of sunlight. The trees are not too tall, but their trunks are as wide as buildings.

The neglected road has been carved into the thicket, an inch at a time, a corridor of plants with a floor made of pebbles that give way to saplings and vines. From time to time, you pass by many turns, relics left by roaming dragons, unicorns, and trolls. Some of them are still used by beasts - boars, striped cats, or packs of goblins.

As you walk away, you’re more than sure that he’s observing each step of yours.
During the ensuing silence, he smiles with an unpleasant look.

Before you even finish the last word, he springs to his feet and dashes away. You hear his steps as he runs through the hill, then lands on a pile of rocks. You glance at your horse - it won’t be able to run on this surface, but also can’t be left behind.

You doubt you’ll ever meet the bandit again.

You hear angry shouts and grunts, then find two brown-furred goblins in a brighter tunnel. Their hairless faces with small eyes and large mouths are now turned toward you.

They are a few steps apart, aiming at each other with one long stick, and one club. Between them is a pair of deer antlers.
I observe them for a bit.
- I observe them for a bit.
With worried, ape-like snorts they totter around, afraid to reach for their find, and not sure where they should fix their gaze. You interrupted a family dispute.
I wait to see what they’re going to do.
- I wait to see what they’re going to do.

After an awkward minute, the goblin with the club drops its weapon, waves its arms, lets out a weak screech, and bites the closest antler. The other one grunts and picks up the second half, and soon after, both creatures flee into the shrubs awkwardly, sparing you only one more glance.
“Let’s go, {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color}.”

You get a bit closer, with your mount towering over the beasts. They exchange looks, let out a gurgle, and crawl away, giving you hateful glances.

After they start to flee through the bushes, you jump on the ground and reach for your prize.

The armed goblins, with brown, gray, and black furs, cease their onslaught a few steps away from you. Some of them move on all fours, while the others stand upright or lean on their weapons, balancing as they walk. They carry clubs, pointed sticks, rusty spears, a broken sword, a cart wheel...

They fearfully observe your mount, until one of the creatures steps forward and gives you a warning grunt. It’s holding a deer antler.
I guess that means we are free to go.

At the edge of the pond you spot a moldy, closed satchel, hanging from one of the branches high above the trail, most likely taken there by an ape or a bird.

Like other trees in this part of the forest, this one is ridiculously wide, covered with dark, scaly bark. It would take time to climb up the slippery lichens.
I shoot it down with my crossbow.

You wait for the wind to calm down. Even though your bolt hits the satchel right in the middle before it gets stuck among the branches, the bag stays where it is, firmly held by its strap.

You stay in the saddle and make a single, swift cut. After the bag falls on the ground, you dismount and spread the contents in the middle of the path.

The foul smell hits your nostrils like a hammer. You ignore the old fruits coated with maggots and eggs, as well as the moldy shirt, but you kick away the small pouch. You cut it open, only to find two dragon bones.
I grab the waterskin to wash them.

You gather the useful tools. Climbing up the trunk without wrapping your arms around it is difficult. After every two or three feet, you cut and tear away slices of bark, making new steps. It gets easier after you reach the first branch strong enough to hold your weight. You secure yourself with the rope.

Once you reach the bag with the satchel, you pull yourself toward it, breaking minor twigs. You pull the leather strap to raise the bag and unpin it.

You find hardly any scraps of light in the tunnel of leaves, creepers, and branches. From time to time, you ride by human-placed wooden beams, supporting the roof like in a mineshaft.

A small, red bird with black wings, blue eyes, and a yellow beak is observing you for a good few minutes now, jumping between the shrubs as you ride forward. You even remember it from the last time you were here. Whenever you stop, it also stays close, like a caring parent.

For a rider, crossing it won’t be much of a problem, but most travelers would have to take off their pants and shoes. Moving an entire wagon would pose quite a challenge.

I’ve restored the stream ford that connects the eastern road with the heart of the forest.

Not unlike the builders from the days before The Ten Cities, you put the last boulder, taming this scrap of the wilderness - even if slightly. The tightly arranged rocks remind you of a cobbled road leading to {color=#f6d6bd}Hovlavan{/color}. Even a wagon carried by two mules could get to the other side without stopping.
I put on my boots and continue my journey.

The rocky hills give way to meadows and tree roots. The saplings wake up beneath the remains of the burnt forest, competing with young grasses and ivies.

At first, the nearby howls make you think of humans, not beasts, but the numerous throats make you reach for your axe. The creatures, not even waist-high, come out from the taller grasses and the sparse bushes, surrounding you quickly. Despite their wolf-like heads, their front paws would fit a monkey. Their furs are mostly brown and short, but carry scars left by all sorts of cuts and scratches. Almost every gnoll lacks a part of its shell - a limb, an ear, a nose, an eye...

Some of them move on all fours and sit down on their rears, while others walk around on their hind legs alone, though with varying levels of confidence. A few have the grace of a determined robber, many more resemble the harbor drunkards.
I consider my options.
- I consider my options.

While you may be able to take a few of them down, they will surely bite into {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]’s{/color} legs. You won’t keep both of you alive.

You could follow one of the old tales, according to which the beastfolk can be {i}bribed{/i} with the gift of food. For now, the beasts are keeping their distance, baring their teeth between their grunts. Sitting in the saddle, you are four times taller than them.
I throw them 3 food rations.
- I throw them 3 food rations.
You lost 3 food rations.
{i}You lost 3 food rations.{/i}

The packages scare away the nearest gnolls, but then the braver ones get closer cautiously, smelling and poking their new booty. Suddenly, they bite into the scraps of linen, revealing the fruits and scraps of meat.

Three of the largest beasts grab your gift - one with its jaws, two with their forelimbs - then run to the hills, followed by the rest of the loud, excited pack.

If the stories are true, the gnolls should now spend some time away from the human eyes.
I pat {color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]’s{/color} side and try to calm its nerves with an encouraging tone.
- I pat {color=#f6d6bd}%s’s{/color} side and try to calm its nerves with an encouraging tone.

It scares away the nearest gnoll, but the others don’t wait even for a moment. The largest one grabs your gift with its jaws, then runs to the hills, followed by the rest of the loud, excited pack - though you’d bet a single bird won’t feed more than four animals of their size.

If the stories are true, the gnolls should now spend some time away from the human eyes.

The first gift scares away the nearest gnolls, but the braver ones don’t wait even for a moment. The largest one bites off a half of it, then leaps away, chomping with joy.

After a short fight over the other half of the meal, the pack turns its eyes toward you. Another two fish land among them, and the beasts that manage to catch them flee toward the hills. Their companions chase after them, without sparing you a glance.

If the stories are true, the gnolls should now spend some time away from the human eyes.

If the stories are true, the gnolls should now spend some time away from the human eyes.

The tiny carcass scares away the nearest gnoll, but the others don’t wait even for a moment. The largest one grabs your gift with its jaws, then runs to the hills, followed by the rest of the loud, excited pack - though you’d bet a single critter won’t feed more than two animals of their size.

If the stories are true, the gnolls should now spend some time away from the human eyes.

As it lands, the nearest gnoll flinches, then gets on all fours and smells it cautiously. It bites into it, but gives you another angry look.
They won’t catch a palfrey. I pretend to turn back, then ride around them, through the rocky meadows.

During the long minutes of maneuvering, the gnolls either try to reach you, or to cut your path. Thankfully, they’re slower than the actual wolves, and too afraid to use their advantage once they get close.

{color=#f6d6bd}[horsename]{/color} is far from being happy, but obeys your orders. You leave the beastfolk behind only once they lose their breath.
